Label: Rape Kit Backlogs Remain in States Despite Funding (230620bs.kits) (267 PV)
Body:
Untested rape kits have piled up in law enforcement facilities and crime labs across the United States, according to nonpartisan data center USAFacts.

A recent report from the nonprofit found that despite Justice Department funding totaling over $1.3 billion since 2011 for programs that contain a focus on clearing backlogs of untested kits, many states have struggled to do so, leaving cases unresolved. Across 30 states and Washington, D.C., USAFacts found at least 25,000 kits in need of testing in 2022.

Rape kits are collected through highly invasive medical examinations with victims of rape or sexual assault, and can last several hours. Typically, kits are sent through law enforcement agencies to be logged as evidence, and then on to forensic labs for testing. But throughout this process, they can end up in a backlog with law enforcement or at the crime lab.

As USAFacts notes, the Justice Department has provided funds to reduce accumulated kits through programs such as the DNA Capacity Enhancement for Backlog Reduction and the National Sexual Assault Kit Initiative. But the organization’s analysis indicates limited success.

Through either a request for information or publicly available reports, USAFacts was able to obtain data from 18 states regarding law enforcement backlogs and from 22 states and the District of Columbia regarding crime lab backlogs.

In the case of law enforcement, Connecticut has maintained no backlog since 2018, while Alaska reported no remaining kits in law enforcement agencies that hadn’t been submitted to a crime lab and New Hampshire had just one unsubmitted kit by the end of 2022. North Carolina was able to reduce its number of untested kits from over 15,000 at the end of 2018 to just 113 by the end of 2022 – a reduction of over 99%. Washington was able to cut its backlog by over 90%, going from 5,855 kits to 585 over the same time period.

[ EXPLORE: Read the USAFacts Report ]

Other states did not see such success. Maryland and Massachusetts had among the largest reported law enforcement backlogs in the country in recent years: Massachusetts managed to reduce its total by only 7% between 2021 and 2022 – the only years for which data for the state was available – while Maryland’s ultimately increased by 10% from 2018 to 2022. Louisiana and Oregon – the latter of which declared a backlog of old kits cleared in 2018 – saw backlogs increase by over 35% between 2018 and 2022, with Texas seeing a 45% increase between 2021 and 2022.

Raw HTML : Number of Untested Kits in State Backlogs, 2018-2022
Meanwhile, in North Carolina’s case, the sheer volume of the more than 15,000 kits sent from law enforcement to crime labs may have ended up backing up the labs tasked with testing them.

By the end of 2022, North Carolina crime labs had over 9,000 kits that had not been tested for at least 30 days. Four other states – Oregon, West Virginia, Louisiana and North Dakota – saw their crime lab backlogs grow by a factor of five or more in that time frame. Overall, just 10 of 20 states that reported crime lab backlogs of any size at some point between 2018 and 2021 had reduced them by 2022.

Notably, some states provided data to USAFacts with different thresholds for a backlog. While the organization requested the number of kits that had been awaiting testing for at least 30 days, Texas provided figures for kits that had gone without testing for 90 days or more. Pennsylvania’s data consisted of kits waiting for more than a year.

Though the total number of backlogged rape kits nationwide is unknown, USAFacts points to a 2022 report from the Congressional Research Service that cited estimates running as high as 400,000 kits unsubmitted to laboratories for the period 2014 to 2018.

As for why the issue persists, the Joyful Heart Foundation’s End the Backlog initiative points to deficiencies in policies and protocols, training, and resources, stating that it costs on average between $1,000 and $1,500 to test a single rape kit. A 2015 report funded by the Department of Justice on unsubmitted kits in Detroit also pointed to victim-blaming among law enforcement personnel as contributing to decisions not to submit kits for testing.

In recent years, survivors in Houston and Memphis have filed lawsuits against officials in relation to untested kits; survivors also have brought suits contesting law enforcement practices in sexual assault investigations.

Some legislators, too, are searching for answers when it comes to kit backlogs. In February, bipartisan members of Congress introduced legislation to reauthorize funding for clearing backlogs, though it remains in committee. States such as Wisconsin and Mississippi have recently approved legislation establishing time requirements for rape kit procedures. And earlier this month, Louisiana Gov. John Bel Edwards signed a bill into law establishing a new tracking system to address his state’s backlog.

Read USAFacts’ methodology here.

If you are seeking information or guidance regarding sexual assault, resources and information are available here.
Subject Tags: sexual assault, rape, Department of Justice, crime

Label: Hunter Biden’s Questionable Case of ‘Special Treatment’ (230621news.hunter) (251 PV)
Body:
Republicans called Hunter Biden's plea agreement on tax and gun-related charges a "sweetheart deal," a "traffic ticket" punishment a less-connected American would not have been offered.

And the president's son may well have gotten special treatment – but not in a good way, tax lawyers and former prosecutors say.

"The tax charges that were filed are not normally tax charges that we would have recommended at the Justice Department. We just don't prioritize failure to file, with a relatively low dollar amount and no sign or evidence of evasion, or an effort to conceal" a scheme to avoid paying taxes, says Brian Galle, a former prosecutor of tax crimes at the Department of Justice.

"By traditional Justice Department criteria, we wouldn't have charged this case," adds Galle, a professor at Georgetown Law. "Mr. Biden's kind of getting worse treatment than a typical defendant would get."

Prominent tax attorney Eric Green notes that "there are more than 10 million non-filers" across the country, but the vast majority are not criminally prosecuted, since it would take an enormous commitment of government resources to take them all to court.

Being famous or politically connected can work against a tax violator, Green and others say, since the government likes to showcase someone whose case will end up in the news. The tax system relies heavily on widespread public compliance, and those stories provide a grim reminder to the less-famous that not paying your taxes can land you in jail. Celebrities, including actor Wesley Snipes, singer Lauryn Hill and baseball player Darryl Strawberry, were sentenced to time behind bars for tax crimes.

"They can't prosecute everyone, so they want to make an example out of people," says tax lawyer Daniel Ryan, a partner at Boston-based Sullivan & Worcester who once worked as an attorney in the IRS's chief counsel's office. The message is, "Look what happened to this guy – it could happen to you," Ryan says.

And with Biden, the Justice Department has an added pressure to prosecute, says Green, a partner at Green & Sklarz in Connecticut. "They have a hostile Republican Congress who's calling for his head. They've indicted Trump. It looks very political if they don't do anything. I think that in some ways, he is getting it worse."

Biden agreed to a plea deal Tuesday for "willful" failure to pay taxes for two years and for failure to note on paperwork for a gun purchase that he had abused drugs. The tax charges, which are misdemeanors, are expected to result in a penalty of probation. The gun-related infraction – based on a law a Texas court has deemed unconstitutional – is expected to be dropped if Biden meets certain, yet unspecified, conditions.

The coming plea has infuriated Republicans, who are vowing to continue their own investigation of both Hunter and President Joe Biden. Hunter Biden, a lawyer and former lobbyist, was on the board of Ukrainian energy company Burisma Holdings when his father was vice president and has done business in China and elsewhere.

Republicans insist there is a deeper scandal, one involving bribes to the elder Biden through his son's business dealings. But aside from Hunter Biden's obvious asset of being related to the then-vice president, GOP investigators have yet to show any criminal connection to the elder Biden.

Republicans had hoped that the five-year Justice Department investigation would produce something more damning about Hunter Biden, or at least a more serious punishment. They claim the department has a double standard, indicting Trump on charges that could well result in prison time while letting Hunter Biden go free.

David Weiss, the prosecutor who led the investigation of Hunter Biden, was appointed by Trump.
Cartoon Gallery : Political Cartoons on President Joe Biden (190816cartoons.joebiden) (1,939 PV)The Trump and Hunter Biden cases are dramatically different: Trump, after all, is accused of not only wrongly possessing classified and other government documents but refusing to give them back even after a subpoena and a search of his home by the FBI. The younger Biden, experts say, could theoretically have faced prison time, but it would have been very unusual for someone in his tax situation.

"I would have argued for probably a year and a half" for someone who owed $200,000, as the Weiss statement said the younger Biden failed to pay, says Boston lawyer Evan Gotlob, a former assistant U.S. attorney who handled public corruption and white-collar crime investigations.

But in cases where Justice might seek 12-18 months behind bars, "it kind of makes sense to plead it out" anyway, since "it's not worth the resources to go to trial," adds Gotlob, now a partner with Saul Ewing.

But unlike other celebrities who indeed went to jail, the younger Biden was not charged with tax evasion but rather a misdemeanor, experts note. Tax evasion, generally speaking, is committed when someone schemes and defrauds to avoid paying taxes, often involving others and spanning several tax years, explains Keith Rosen, former chief of the criminal division for the U.S. Attorney's Office for the District of Delaware.

If someone merely fails to pay taxes – even when he or she knew it was required by law – the infraction is a misdemeanor. says Rosen, now at the global law firm of Norton Rose Fulbright.

"If you look at the statistics, you would find that those [misdemeanor charges] are frequently offenses that don't result in prison. The Justice Department is not in the business – and the IRS is not in the business – of regularly charging people with misdemeanor tax offenses," Rosen adds.

As for the gun charge, people typically aren't prosecuted for it unless it's part of some other illegal conduct or if the defendant has a criminal history, Rosen says.

"I'm not surprised there was a settlement. Settlements in regard to tax matters are relatively common," says Eric Chaffee, a law professor at Case Western University School of Law.

"With the election coming up relatively soon, it only benefits the Biden camp if the Hunter Biden matter is put behind them. There was an incentive to get a settlement, and these things are relatively common. But this is not a common case," since it involves the president's son, he adds. Republicans, meanwhile, are determined to keep the matter alive and in the public eye.
Subject Tags: Biden, Hunter, Biden, Joe, taxes, courts

Label: Search for Titanic Tourist Submersible Ramps Up After Underwater Noises Heard (230621news.titanic) (715 PV)
Body:
The U.S. Coast Guard on Wednesday said it is bringing in additional search vessels after a Canadian airplane detected underwater noises during the search for a missing submersible carrying five people to look at the wreckage of the Titanic in the Atlantic Ocean.
Related Link Enhancement : Search for Titanic Tour Sub Intensifies (https://www.usnews.com/news/world-report/articles/2023-06-20/search-intensifies-for-missing-titanic-tourist-submersible)Data on the noises is so far “inconclusive,” officials said during a press briefing on Wednesday.

“We need to have hope, but I can’t tell you what the noises are,” Capt. Jamie Frederick of the U.S. Coast Guard said.

The noises were detected on Tuesday and Wednesday, he said. But officials cautioned that many things could make such noises – including undersea animals.

“We don’t know what they are, to be frank with you,” Frederick said, adding that they are searching in the area where the noises were detected.
Photo Gallery : Photos You Should See - June 2023 (230606gallery.june23_pyss) (1,328 PV)The search mission, which now covers a surface area that is two times the size of Connecticut, is “incredibly complex,” according to Frederick.

The submersible, named “Titan,” went missing on Sunday and may have less than a day’s worth of oxygen left. Frederick said the vessel is carrying limited rations of food and water as well.

The five people on board the Titan are a British adventurer, two members of a Pakistani business family and a French maritime expert along with pilot Stockton Rush, the CEO of the OceanGate Expeditions company that runs the trips.
Related Link Enhancement : Missing Titanic Sub: When It Vanished and the Race to Find It (https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2023-06-21/missing-titanic-sub-when-it-vanished-and-the-race-to-find-it)If the vessel is on or near the surface of the ocean, a rescue mission would be relatively straightforward. But if the submersible is deep underwater, a rescue becomes much more difficult. Officials are working to find equipment that could be used for such a mission.

The Titanic sank in 1912 after hitting an iceberg during its first voyage from Britain to New York, killing about 1,500 people. The wreckage was discovered at a depth of about 12,500 feet – or more than 2 miles – below the surface in 1985.

Frederick did not speculate as to when the search may end.

“Sometimes you’re in a position where you have to make a tough decision,” he said. “We’re not there yet.”
Subject Tags: oceans, Coast Guard

Label: Poll: Republicans Prioritize Principles Over Electability Ahead of ‘24 (230621news.gop) (292 PV)
Body:
Republicans really want to beat President Joe Biden in 2024. But the rank-and-file voters in the party aren't making that a priority when deciding whom to pick as the presidential nominee, according to a poll released Wednesday.
Related Link Enhancement : Poll: Majority Wants Trump to Drop Out (https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2023-06-16/poll-majority-says-trump-should-drop-out-of-presidential-race)The Marist Institute of Public Opinion found that 63% of Republicans and GOP-leaning independent voters believe it is more important to nominate someone who stands on conservative principles, while 35% said it's more important to pick someone who can defeat Biden.

"Republicans want their party to stay true to its core, conservative principles," Lee Miringoff, director of the nonpartisan Marist Institute, said in a statement. "Electability may emerge as an important factor down the road when the nominees for both parties are in place. But right now, it’s not Republicans’ top priority."

That's positive news for former President Donald Trump, who leads in national polls and most statewide polls for the Republican nomination. While other surveys have shown increasing voter concern over Trump's second indictment, a 37-count series of felony charges involving his handling of classified and other government documents, the Marist poll suggests his devoted base is sticking with him.
Cartoon Gallery : Cartoons on the 2024 Presidential Election (230501cartoons.2024elections) (101 PV)In fact, while both Marist last week and CNN on Tuesday released polling showing that most voters believe the indictment means Trump should get out of the race, Wednesday's Marist survey found that Trump's standing has grown among GOP voters. More than three-fourths (76%) of Republicans and GOP-leaning independents have a positive view of Trump, the Wednesday poll found, up from 68% who reported feeling that way in February.

The poll is also potentially good news for Biden, who appears likely to secure the Democratic nomination again despite rank-and-file concerns about the 80-year-old president's age. Biden has cast himself as the Democrat most able to beat Trump, noting that he’s done it once before.

Several polls over the past months show that overall, voters do not want to see another Biden-Trump face-off, but even Democratic voters who didn't want the president to run again will support him anyway.

An NBC poll in April, for example, found that 51% of Democrats didn't want Biden as the nominee, but 88% of Democrats said they would definitely or probably vote for him regardless of the fact that he is not their first choice.

For Biden, there is less of a choice, since the incumbent vastly overshadows his primary opponents, in terms of both visibility and fundraising, and enjoys formal party backing.
Related Link Enhancement : Just Another Day on the Campaign Trail (https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2023-06-13/trump-treats-arraignment-as-another-day-on-the-campaign-trail)For Trump, the question is more complicated. While he enjoys the advantages of being a former president – including the fundraising donor lists and the loyal support of a core group of voters who believe he was cheated out of the 2020 win – Trump has a pack of GOP primary foes waiting for him to fall.

The former president is well ahead of his competitors in polls, and the devotion of his base means he could be the GOP field’s strongest candidate against Biden. But his standing could plummet if and when his legal situation worsens.

Trump's criminal trial in New York is scheduled for March 25 – a critical point in the primary season – and a Florida judge set Aug. 14 as the trial date for the government documents case against him (though legal experts believe the trial will be delayed).

Should Trump fall, one of his opponents could try to take the conservative mantle. But only two of Trump's GOP primary challengers – Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis and Sen. Tim Scott of South Carolina – have approval ratings above 50% among Republican voters, Marist found.

DeSantis, who is running a distant second to Trump in primary polls, has an approval rating of 67% among Republicans, Marist found, while Scott has a favorability rating of 50%. For now, the nomination appears to be Trump's to lose.
Subject Tags: Republican Party, elections, presidential elections, polls, voters, Biden, Joe

Label: Earnest Student Loans Review (190124loans.lenderreview.earneststudent) (26 PV)
Body:
Raw HTML : Borrower Tip Lender ProfileLender Rate Table : Student Loans - In-school Rate Table

Student loan options from Earnest include:
  • Undergraduate loans.
  • Graduate loans.
  • MBA, medical or law school loans.
  • Parent loans.
  • Co-signer loans.
  • Student loan refinancing.

Earnest asks applicants to submit their education and employment history for a full picture of their achievements. The company also considers your or your co-signer's credit score, credit history, and income. Students can apply for undergraduate or graduate student loans online and typically receive a response within 72 hours. Earnest also allows student loan applications to be submitted over the phone. Once approved, students can pick a payment plan or defer repayment for nine months post-graduation. The process could take between two to five weeks for the loan to be funded, depending on the applicant and the school's financial aid office.https://www.earnest.com/student-loans/undergraduate https://help.earnest.com/hc/en-us/articles/218389588-How-is-the-Earnest-application-different-

Earnest's student loans and refinancing are available at both fixed and variable rates. You can choose a loan term of between five to 20 years. The minimum in-school loan amount is $1,000, https://help.earnest.com/hc/en-us/articles/360021312574-What-are-the-minimum-and-maximum-loan-amount-I-can-take-Private-Student-Loans and loans of up to 100% of the school's certified cost of attendance are available. There is no application, origination or late fee.

There is a 0.25-percentage-point interest rate discount if you choose to set up automatic payments. Borrowers can choose their monthly payment amount while still in school when applying for the loan. Accounts in good standing can skip a payment once every 12 months, but it has to be paid later. Earnest's nine-month grace period after graduation is longer than the typical six months that other student loan lenders offer.

Earnest will also match a competitor's contractual interest rate for an in-school loan, excluding discounts for autopay or good grades. To qualify, borrowers need to contact Earnest's customer service team and upload a loan agreement from a competitor. If approved, the borrower can view and sign an updated agreement in their Earnest account. The competitor offer must have been made within the last 30 days and meet other conditions. Once your rate match is finalized, Earnest will give you a $100 Amazon gift card.

Earnest offers a quick online eligibility check so you can get an idea of whether you qualify without a hard inquiry on your credit report. Earnest has different eligibility requirements for each loan type.

To qualify for an independent undergraduate or graduate student loan, borrowers must:
  • Be pursuing a bachelor's or graduate degree.
  • Have at least a three-year credit history.
  • Show no bankruptcies on your credit report.
  • Have an income of at least $35,000 for an undergraduate loan.
  • Other factors for approval include having a history of making payments on time, avoiding overdraft and insufficient funds fees and avoiding a large amount of credit card debt. https://www.earnest.com/eligibility
Co-signed student loans require:
  • The co-signer to have a minimum of a three-year credit history.
  • Have at least $35,000 in annual income.
  • Both the co-signer and the student cannot have any bankruptcies or accounts in collections.
  • The lender also considers whether you have a history of making payments on time, avoiding overdraft and insufficient funds fees, not taking on a large amount of credit card debt and spending less than you earn.
For refinancing student loans, you must:
  • Request to refinance at least $5,000 in loans. California residents must refinance $10,000 or more, and New Mexico residents must refinance $10,001 or more if they use Earnest.
  • Be employed or have a consistent income.
  • Have student loan accounts in good standing.
  • Be current on your rent or mortgage payments.
  • Other factors for approval include having enough savings to cover two months of expenses, spending less than you earn and having a history of making payments on time.
Borrowers may be able to refinance a loan for a completed degree, a degree that will be completed by the end of the semester or a degree that hasn't been completed. For the latter, borrowers must meet these requirements:
  • Their last attending date must be more than six years ago.
  • Their credit score should be 700 or higher.
  • The school they attended wasn't for-profit. https://www.earnest.com/eligibility

Earnest student loans require either the borrower or co-signer to have a FICO score of at least 650. In the application process, Earnest also looks at an individual's education and employment history – putting less weight on the credit score.

For student loan refinancing, Earnest requires a credit score of 680. Those who haven't completed their degree may need to have a score of 700.

Earnest offers loans in Washington, D.C., and in all states except Nevada. It also doesn't offer student loan refinancing in Kentucky.

Earnest is accredited and has an A+ rating with the Better Business Bureau.https://www.bbb.org/us/ca/san-francisco/profile/loans/earnest-1116-464517 It also has an excellent rating of 4.7 out of 5 stars with Trustpilot, based on more than 5,500 reviews. https://www.trustpilot.com/review/earnest.com

In 2022, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau received 17https://www.consumerfinance.gov/data-research/consumer-complaints/search/?company=Earnest%20Inc.&date_received_max=2022-12-31&date_received_min=2022-01-01&page=1&product=Student%20loan&searchField=company&size=25&sort=created_date_desc&tab=List student loan complaints about Earnest. The most common issue was related to dealing with the lender or servicer, mainly regarding how payments were handled or receiving bad information. Earnest provided a timely response to all issues, and all were closed with explanation.

Earnest offers a chat feature directly on its website, as well as space to send an email. To speak to a representative, call 888-601-2801. To submit a student loan application over the phone, call 866-492-1222. Business hours are Monday through Friday from 5 a.m. until 5 p.m. Pacific Time.

Applicants can apply directly through the website and upload all documents to their Earnest account. https://help.earnest.com/hc/en-us/articles/221780648-How-can-I-provide-Earnest-with-my-documents-#:~:text=You%20can%20upload%20a%20file,to%20upload%20the%20appropriate%20file. Borrowers may see upcoming payments and payment history through their Earnest dashboard, set up automatic payments, change payment dates and reach out to customer service representatives during business hours through its chat feature.

Earnest does not have prepayment penalties, so borrowers can make payments for more than the full monthly payment amount. Borrowers have four payment options while still in school:
  • Deferred payment: Borrowers wait until nine months after graduation to begin making payments.
  • Fixed $25 payment: For this option, borrowers make small monthly payments while in school so they can reduce the amount of interest they accrue.
  • Interest-only payment: This involves paying the accrued interest each month during school.
  • Principal and interest payment: Borrowers who choose this option start making full payments right away, with no grace period.

Forbearance due to financial hardship is available. However, specific qualification requirements are not disclosed. Loans may be discharged due to death or permanent disability.

  • Students who want the option to borrow with or without a co-signer.
  • Graduates who need to refinance student loans.
  • Borrowers who want to choose their monthly payment and loan terms.
Lender Rate Table : Student Loans - Refinance Rate Table

Label: China Blasts ‘Absurd’ Biden Reference to Xi as Ill-Informed ‘Dictator’ (230621news.china) (623 PV)
Body:
President Xi Jingping’s government on Wednesday professed outrage at President Joe Biden’s dismissive reference to China’s leader as a “dictator” at a fundraising event late Tuesday – an apparent attempt to gain a rhetorical edge over Beijing.
Related Link Enhancement : General Warns of India-China Clashes (https://www.usnews.com/news/world-report/articles/2023-03-31/top-general-warns-of-concerning-chinese-activities-along-border-with-india)“It is a blatant provocation. China expresses strong dissatisfaction and opposition,” Mao Ning, a spokeswoman for China’s Foreign Ministry, told reporters early Wednesday. “The U.S. remarks are extremely absurd and irresponsible.”

Speaking at a campaign fundraiser in California on Tuesday evening, Biden mocked what he framed as Xi’s ignorance about the circumstances leading up to a potential international crisis earlier this year when a Chinese spy balloon drifted across North America before a fighter jet shot it down off the coast of South Carolina.

“The reason why Xi Jinping got very upset in terms of when I shot that balloon down with two boxcars full of spy equipment in it is he didn’t know it was there,” Biden said.

“That’s what’s a great embarrassment for dictators – when they didn’t know what happened,” he added. “That wasn’t supposed to be going where it was. It was blown off course up through Alaska and then down through the United States. And he didn’t know about it. When it got shot down, he was very embarrassed.”
Cartoon Gallery : Vladimir Putin, Kim Jong Un, Emmanuel Macron and More: Political Cartoons on World Leaders (190306cartoons.worldleaders) (2,270 PV)Biden did not explain the source of the assertions, which appear to be based on U.S. intelligence assessments of the aftermath of the balloon incident.

What was ostensibly a passing jibe from the 2024 Democratic presidential candidate is widely seen as an attempt to burnish his tough-on-China credentials days after Secretary of State Antony Blinken traveled to Beijing and met with Xi to slow the steady deterioration of relations between the world’s two largest powers. The rhetoric will all but certainly continue to heat up as Biden positions himself for reelection against a challenger from the Republican Party, which has consistently criticized his handling of Chinese economic and military aggression.

China has likewise attempted to portray the high-profile summit with the visiting diplomat as an example of U.S. acquiescence – a narrative Biden’s domestic political rivals, too, are eager to embrace.

Republicans have widely condemned the optics of Blinken’s trip, including imagery China has widely proliferated showing the chief U.S. diplomat sitting at a table in a grand meeting room listening to Xi, seated at the head and conspicuously higher up. Chinese state media has also drawn subtle attention to the fact the meeting took place on Father’s Day, suggesting that Beijing is moving toward a paternal relationship with America.

Blinken himself balked at questions on Tuesday when asked if the U.S. president sees his Chinese counterpart as an equal.

“I’m not quite sure how to take that question,” Blinken said from London, where he was traveling for a meeting with Ukraine’s international benefactors about reconstruction for the war-torn country. “President Xi is the leader of China and, in and of itself, that makes him someone of tremendous significance on the world stage.”
Related Link Enhancement : China’s Growing Influence as an International Mediator (https://www.usnews.com/news/world-report/articles/2023-03-16/chinas-growing-influence-as-an-international-mediator)Aside from the balloon flap earlier this year, the summit also came amid reports China is investing heavily in new military and intelligence presences in Cuba – details first reported by The Wall Street Journal that the White House has subsequently downplayed as a potential threat it has already begun to address.

“China is trying to improve their global reach and influence and, again, their global intelligence collection capabilities,” John Kirby, a spokesman for the National Security Council, told reporters on a teleconference this week. “It's not like we aren't aware of it, it's not like we haven't been monitoring it and, quite frankly, it's not like we haven't taken steps and will continue to take steps to thwart it.”

Rep. Mike McCaul, Texas Republican and chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, blasted the summit as wasteful and said the Biden administration’s latest overtures to the Chinese Communist Party are deeply concerning and effectively toothless.

“Blinken brushing off the recent CCP spy balloon that traversed the U.S. was ridiculous and totally dismissive of the concerns of the American people,” the Texas Republican said in a statement in which also lamented what he considered Blinken’s inability to address other issues such as climate change, fentanyl imports to Mexico or returning Americans detained in China. “And just as troubling – China’s recent agreement with Cuba to house a CCP military training facility was not addressed during these meetings.
Subject Tags: China, Biden, Joe, Blinken, Antony, world news

Label: What Is Gender-Affirming Care, and Which States Have Restricted it in 2023? (230621bs.gender) (350 PV)
Body:
A large majority of transgender adults in the United States – 78% – say living with a gender different from the one assigned to them at birth has made them more satisfied with their lives, according to a recent survey from The Washington Post and Kaiser Family Foundation.
Related Link Enhancement : Montana Bill to Deny Care for Transgender Minors Passes (https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/montana/articles/2023-03-29/montana-bill-to-deny-care-for-transgender-minors-passes)Among respondents, more than three-quarters had changed their type of clothing, hairstyle or grooming habits to align with their preferred gender, while 31% had used hormone treatments and 16% had undergone gender-affirming surgery or a related surgical treatment to alter their appearance.

But such options are becoming available on a more limited basis, as politicians in several states have attempted to restrict trans Americans’ ability to seek gender-affirming medical treatments. In some states, such as Georgia and Tennessee, bans for minors have already been enacted in the first quarter of 2023.

What Is Gender-Affirming Care? 


The Human Rights Campaign, a LGBTQ+ advocacy group, defines gender-affirming care as “age-appropriate care that is medically necessary for the well-being of many transgender and non-binary people who experience symptoms of gender dysphoria, or distress that results from having one’s gender identity not match their sex assigned at birth.” The organization notes both the American Medical Association and American Academy of Pediatrics support “age-appropriate, gender-affirming care for transgender and non-binary people.”

Conservatives often oppose the concept of gender-affirming care – which may or may not include surgical or other interventions – for various reasons, including religious beliefs and concerns about child abuse. “You don’t disfigure 10-, 12-, 13-year-old kids based on gender dysphoria,” Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis, a Republican, said at an August news conference.

Some have expressed concern about a lack of data on the possible long-term consequences of gender-affirming medical treatment for minors. A Reuters investigation, for example, found “no large-scale studies have tracked people who received gender-related medical care as children to determine how many remained satisfied with their treatment as they aged and how many eventually regretted transitioning.” Others, according to the article, have raised alarms about children who are not appropriately evaluated before receiving gender-affirming medical care.

These States Have Banned Gender-Affirming Care

  • Arkansas
  • Florida
  • Georgia
  • Idaho
  • Indiana
  • Iowa
  • Kentucky
  • Mississippi
  • Missouri
  • Montana
  • Nebraska
  • North Dakota
  • Oklahoma
  • South Dakota
  • Tennessee
  • Texas
  • Utah
  • West Virginia
Below are the states that have restricted some form of gender-affirming care for minors so far in 2023, based largely on legislation tracking from the Equality Federation, an advocacy accelerator that works with a network of state-based LGBTQ+ organizations.

Some states, such as Arizona and Alabama, passed bans prior to this year and are not included on the list. Alabama’s law has since been blocked by a federal judge as it faces a challenge in court.

Dozens of bills are still being considered by lawmakers in other states, according to the federation. And officials elsewhere, including in Florida and Missouri, have bypassed state legislatures altogether.


    Arkansas

    Signed into law by new Republican Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders in March, Arkansas’ law will make health care providers liable for civil action for up to 15 years after a minor turns 18 if they performed a gender transition procedure on that minor – essentially making it easier to file malpractice lawsuits in these situations. On that note, experts say the law acts as a de facto ban on gender-affirming care for children because it makes it nearly impossible for providers to get malpractice insurance, according to the AP. In 2021, state lawmakers passed the nation’s first ban on gender-affirming care for minors. The move was temporarily blocked shortly after, but on June 20, 2023, a federal judge issued a permanent injunction against it, ruling the ban unconstitutional. It marked the first time such a state ban was overturned, but the more recent law signed by Sanders was still set to go into effect.


    Florida

    The state Department of Health’s Board of Medicine announced a new rule in March that prohibits several types of therapies and procedures for treating gender dysphoria in minors. The methods of care covered include sex reassignment surgeries and puberty blocking therapies. Minors already being treated with the rule’s referenced therapies prior to the effective date of it were allowed to continue. Then, on May 17, DeSantis signed into law a similar gender-affirming care ban from the state legislature, which, in addition to prohibiting procedures from being performed on minors, also grants Florida courts “temporary emergency jurisdiction” over a child if they have been subjected to or “threatened” with sex-reassignment prescriptions or procedures. The law also requires transgender adults to get written consent before undergoing such procedures by using a form adopted by the Board of Medicine and Board of Osteopathic Medicine, according to Reuters. But on June 6, a district court judge in Florida issued a preliminary injunction that temporarily blocked enforcement of some parts of the law.


    Georgia

    Senate Bill 140 was signed into law by Georgia’s Republican Gov. Brian Kemp in late March. The legislation, pushed forward by the Republican majority in the state’s General Assembly, prohibits “certain surgical procedures for the treatment of gender dysphoria in minors from being performed in hospitals and other licensed healthcare facilities.” There are exceptions, including treatments that are deemed “medically necessary” and situations covering continued treatment for minors undergoing “irreversible hormone replacement therapies” prior to July 1, 2023.

    Idaho

    The state’s GOP Gov. Brad Little approved a bill that criminalizes providing gender-affirming care for youth. Signed on April 4 and going into effect in January 2024, the law makes it a felony to provide hormones, puberty blockers or other gender-affirming medical care to minors. Little said in a letter confirming the bill signing that policymakers “should take great caution whenever we consider allowing the government to interfere with loving parents and their decisions about what is best for their children.”

    Indiana

    Republican Gov. Eric Holcomb signed into law on April 5 a bill banning all gender-affirming care for minors, after previously saying there was “some vagueness to it,” according to the AP. The governor said in a statement that “permanent gender-changing surgeries with lifelong impacts and medically prescribed preparation for such a transition should occur as an adult, not as a minor.” Parts of the law, however, were blocked by a federal judge on June 16 following a request for a preliminary injunction by the American Civil Liberties Union of Indiana. The order stops the law’s ban on puberty blockers and hormone treatments for minors from going into force on July 1, but does not impact the restriction on gender-affirming surgeries.

    Iowa

    Iowa’s ban, which was made law on March 22, prohibits health care professionals from “knowingly” performing certain medical practices on minors if they are “for the purpose of attempting to alter the appearance of, or affirm the minor’s perception of, the minor's gender or sex, if that appearance or perception is inconsistent with the minor's sex.” Practices covered by the law include hormone therapies and surgical procedures. As with other states’ laws, there are some exceptions, including a “medically verifiable disorder of sex development.”

    Kentucky

    The state on March 29 joined others in banning gender-affirming medical care for minors when the Republican-led Kentucky general assembly voted to override Democratic Gov. Andy Beshear’s veto. The law notes that any health provider who violates this prohibition would have their license or certificate revoked. Kentucky is the only state led by a Democrat to enact a gender-affirming care ban so far in 2023.

    Mississippi

    Mississippi’s law – among the first to be enacted in 2023 – bans any person from knowingly providing or engaging in conduct that aids and abets the performance of gender transition procedures on a minor in the state. The ban also prohibits the use of public funds or tax deductions for such procedures. Republican Gov. Tate Reeves claimed when he signed the bill into law that “radical activists” are telling children they are “just a surgery away from happiness,” according to the AP.

    Missouri

    GOP Gov. Mike Parson on June 7 signed a bill that will restrict gender-affirming health care for minors and some adults in Missouri starting in late August. The law prevents the state’s Medicaid division from covering such treatment for people of any age, and prohibits providers from prescribing puberty-blockers or cross-sex hormones to minors until Aug. 28, 2027, unless they were being treated prior to the bill’s effective date. Missouri initially banned gender-affirming care in April through an emergency regulation from the state attorney general that limited treatments for both minors and adults, the latter of which was believed to be a first in the country. But Attorney General Andrew Bailey terminated the rule – which had already been on pause due to a lawsuit – on May 16, citing the state legislature’s imminent ban. Bailey said in a statement about the original emergency rule, “When even progressive countries like Sweden, Norway, Finland, and the United Kingdom have all sharply curtailed these procedures, it’s time for the United States to course correct.”

    Montana

    Signed into law on April 28 by Republican Gov. Greg Gianforte, Montana’s ban on gender-affirming care for minors covers both surgical procedures and medications such as puberty blockers and testosterone. As with other state laws, the prohibition has exceptions including for someone “diagnosed with a disorder of sexual development.” Any physician who performs a banned procedure can be also sued in the 25 years following it if the after-effects result in any injury, “including physical, psychological, emotional or physiological harms.” The law takes effect on Oct. 1, according to the AP. Democratic state Rep. Zooey Zephyr, a transgender woman, was exiled from the Montana House floor after she said her fellow Republican lawmakers would have “blood on their hands” if they passed the bill.

    Nebraska

    Republican Gov. Jim Pillen signed into law on May 22 a bill that prohibits gender-affirming medical care for minors, which covers people under the age of 19 in Nebraska. The law, which also bans abortions at 12 weeks of pregnancy, includes a ban on surgical procedures and limitations on “prescribed drugs related to gender alteration.” The rules for the latter are to be determined by the state’s chief medical officer – a political appointee, according to the AP. The gender-affirming care portion of the new law goes into effect on Oct. 1, 2023.

    North Dakota

    Republican Gov. Doug Burgum on April 19 signed a veto-proof bill into law that criminalizes providing gender-affirming medical care to minors. The law, which went into effect immediately as an “emergency measure,” makes performing sex reassignment surgery on a minor a felony, and makes providing gender-affirming medication such as puberty blockers to minors a misdemeanor. Burgum recommended in a statement that “thoughtful debate around these complex medical policies should demonstrate compassion and understanding for all North Dakota youth and their families,” according to the AP.

    Oklahoma

    GOP Gov. Kevin Stitt on May 1 signed into law a ban on gender-affirming care for minors in Oklahoma, saying he was “thrilled” to do so and “protect our kids.” The bill allows for any physician who knowingly provides gender transition procedures to be charged with a felony, but the prosecution must occur before the minor patient turns 45. The law went into effect immediately, but on May 18 the state agreed to not enforce it while opponents sought a temporary court order blocking it.

    South Dakota

    Signed into law on Feb. 13, House Bill 1080 prohibits South Dakotan health care professionals from administering various types of gender-affirming procedures on minors. If a provider violates the law, the legislation requires a professional or occupational licensing board to revoke any license or certificate held by the provider. GOP Gov. Kristi Noem strongly supported the bill before signing it, according to the AP.

    Tennessee

    Tennessee’s legislation, which became law in late March but goes into effect on July 1, bans health care providers from performing or offering to perform a medical procedure on a minor if its purpose is to enable that minor “to identify with, or live as, a purported identity inconsistent with the immutable characteristics of the reproductive system that define the minor as male or female.” It also prohibits such procedures if the purpose is to treat “purported discomfort or distress from a discordance between the minor's sex and asserted identity.” There are exceptions, and the law establishes penalties for providers who violate it.

    Texas

    GOP Gov. Greg Abbott on June 2 signed a bill banning gender-affirming care for minors in Texas. The law, which goes into effect on Sept. 1, contains exceptions similar to other states’ efforts at restricting transition care. This is not Texas’ first attempt at limiting gender-affirming care: Abbott in 2022 ordered the investigation of families who were receiving such care, but the order was halted by a judge in the state.

    Utah

    Republican Gov. Spencer Cox signed into law on Jan. 28 the first gender-affirming care ban of the year. The Utah legislature’s Senate Bill 16 restricts health providers from performing “sex characteristic surgical procedures on a minor for the purpose of effectuating a sex change” or hormonal transgender treatment on minors who weren’t diagnosed with gender dysphoria before July 1, 2023. Cox said his approval of the law was an effort at least in part to pause “these permanent and life-altering treatments for new patients until more and better research can help determine the long-term consequences,” the AP reported.

    West Virginia

    A new law signed by GOP Gov. Jim Justice on March 29 prohibits minors from being prescribed hormone therapy and puberty blockers, or from receiving gender-affirming surgery. The law, which will take effect in January 2024, contains an exception geared toward youth for whom “treatment with pubertal modulating and hormonal therapy is medically necessary to treat the minor’s psychiatric symptoms and limit self-harm, or the possibility of self-harm.” In these cases, the minor must receive consent from their parents or guardians along with two medical providers.
Subject Tags: Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Mississippi, South Dakota, Tennessee, Utah, transgender people

The Fourth of July brings tons of festivities and food to enjoy. Whether you're hosting a backyard barbecue, planning a picnic, or gathering in your community for epic fireworks, you'll want to know where to grab last-minute items in case you forget anything.

If your plans include scoring some holiday savings, you're also in luck. Many retailers are hosting 4th of July sales and will also be open on the holiday itself, which falls on a Tuesday this year. Fourth of July is known to have great deals on home products like furniture, appliances, and mattresses.

To make sure you find everything you need on Independence Day, we've compiled the stores that will be open that day. Most grocery stores, convenience stores, and other retailers will be open on the 4th of July, with the major exception of Costco, which will be closed for the holiday.

Remember to call your local store before you head out, as individual stores and pharmacies may have different hours.

Label: Top Amazon Prime Day Deals 2023 (220711_topamazonprimedays) (39 PV)
Body:
Raw HTML : Deals Articles Small Disclaimer Prices are still high thanks to inflation, so it’s more important than ever to save money where you can. While Black Friday, Cyber Monday, and other holiday weekends are known for big sales, another shopping holiday might just offer the best savings of all: Amazon Prime Day.

This year the event takes place July 11-12. During this two-day savings bonanza, Prime members can find deep discounts on everything from clothing and beauty supplies to Amazon devices, electronics, home goods, apparel, and toys.

Amazon Prime Day is only available to Prime members, so the general public won't have access to these deals. A Prime membership will run you $14.99 per month or $139 annually. Students and select government-assistance recipients can join Prime for $7.49 per month or $69 per year.

However, if you’re not ready to commit to a plan but want to shop Prime Day deals, consider starting a 30-day free trial during the sales event. You can take advantage of Amazon's free trial if you haven't been a Prime member within the previous 12 months.

Shopping the Amazon Prime Day sale can be overwhelming, so it’s a good idea to start planning early. We’ve rounded up some of the best Amazon Prime Day deals from last year to help you get an idea of what to expect when the sales event kicks off this year.

Amazon Prime Day Deals To Expect

Amazon Prime Day is packed with thousands of deals across product categories – all within two days. To prep for the shopping event ahead of time, here are the deals you can expect to see this year based on last year’s best discounts:

Apparel Deals


We’re expecting markdowns on various clothing and accessory brands during the 48-hour event. If you’re looking to expand your style or revamp your wardrobe, you’ll likely find pieces for all occasions on sale. Last year, shoppers could find the following deals:
  • Ray-Ban: The eyewear retailer marked down select eyewear options for men and women up to 30%.
  • Oakley: The sporty shades brand discounted select sunglasses up to 30% off.
  • Levi’s: This jeans brand lowered prices by up to 40% on select jeans and apparel styles for men and women.
  • Merrell: The outerwear retailer marked down its Moab 2 hiking boots by 41%.
  • Reebok: The sneaker brand discounted several styles for men and women.
  • Columbia: This sportswear brand featured discounts up to 50% on select apparel and accessories.
  • Calvin Klein: The fashion designer slashed prices on underwear for men and women by up to 30%.

Tech Deals


Laptops, TVs, Amazon devices, and other electronics are sure to be on sale this year. Prime Day always features deep discounts on tech products, especially Amazon branded products. To get an idea of what to expect, check out these deals from 2022:
  • Laptops: Shoppers saw savings of up to $200 off Apple Macbooks, up to $175 off several Lenovo models, and steep savings on Asus, Acer, and Samsung laptops.
  • TVs: Amazon Fire TVs were up to 79% off, the LG C1 65-inch OLED TV was discounted $703, and the Samsung QN90A 65-inch QLED TV was 27% off. The last two models rank in our Best TVs rating.
  • Headphones and earbuds: Amazon shoppers found up to a $100 discount on Apple AirPods, up to $90 off Samsung Galaxy Buds, and more than $100 off Bose headphones.
  • Home security: The Google Nest Cam was $90 off, select Eufy products were $100 off, and the GE Cync outdoor camera was $34 off.
  • Home theaters: Prime members saw $1,396 off an LG projector, $170 off a Samsung sound bar, and $20 off Amazon Fire and Roku TV sticks.
  • Smartwatches: Samsung Galaxy Watch 4 models were up to 30% off, Fitbit watches were up to 43% off, and select Apple watches were up to $120 off.

Home Goods Deals


If you miss Fourth of July sales on appliances and mattresses, you can still find deals during Amazon Prime Day. Vacuums, mattresses, and small kitchen appliances are all expected to see steep price reductions. Here's a look at home goods deals from last year:
    • Vacuums: Shark vacuums were up to 45% off, select iRobot products were up to 40% off, and the Bissell Crosswave Pet Pro was 36% off.
    • Air fryers: Deals included select Cosori air fryers up to $54 off, almost 30% off the Ninja Foodi 12-in-1 Deluxe XL, and up 50% off select Instant Pot models.
    • Air purifiers: The Coway Airmega 400S was almost 50% off, Levoit's compact air purifier was marked down 30%, and the Honeywell HPA300 was 51% off.
    • Mattresses: Casper mattresses were up to 25% off, the Zinus Green Tea mattress was 45% off, and other discounts included Lucid, Serta, and Tuft & Needle models.
    • Pillows: During last year's sale, 20% was deducted from the Coop Home Goods Eden Pillow and Original Pillow and $20 was taken off the Casper Original Pillow.

    Child and Baby Products Deals


    For parents, Amazon Prime Day brings mid-year discounts to baby apparel and supplies along with toys and games for all ages. Big brands like Hanes, Gerber, Disney, and Fisher-Price are expected to see markdowns just like last year. These are some of the deals we saw in 2022:
    • Toys: Select Lego, Fisher-Price, and Mattel toys were up to 30% off, along with Disney, Star Wars, and Harry Potter products.
    • Games: More than 30 games were free from Prime Gaming along with 50% off New World games – the biggest discount on the brand at the time.
    • Baby items: Diapers and baby wipes were discounted up to 30% off, and apparel from Gerber and Hanes was up to 40% off.
    Along with all the deals we listed, thousands more discounts were available during Amazon Prime Day 2022. You can expect to see deals on just about everything during the 2023 event.

    How Long Do Amazon Prime Day Deals Last?

    Amazon Prime Day deals officially last two days, but some may only last one day or be a Lightning Deal that's good for only a few hours. In addition, some products may sell out quickly. If you find a deal you like, its best to act on it as soon as you can.

    Prime Day isn’t the only opportunity to save money at Amazon. You can shop its Deal of the Day section all year round for special 24-hour discounts on a variety of categories. The retailer also offers Lightning Deals throughout the day all year long.

    Tips for Finding the Best Amazon Prime Day Deals 

    Yes, Amazon Prime Day is a huge savings event that will have you wanting to add just about everything to your cart. Before you complete your purchase, be sure you’re getting the best deal. Here are some tips for finding the best Amazon Prime Day deals:

    Beware of fake reviews


    Reviews with glaring grammatical errors or products that have a high percentage of five-star reviews and almost as many one-star reviews can be red flags. But there are ways to weed out fake reviews. Browser extensions like Fakespot will grade each item from A to F based on whether the reviews seem legitimate. Keep in mind the grade refers to the quality of the reviews – it's not a review of the product.

    Compare prices


    Some large retailers hold their own rival sales during Prime Day. Target is running its Deal Days event July 11-13. Best Buy is also known for competing with Prime Day by holding its own Black Friday in July savings event.

    Do your research


    Have a list of items you're interested in and research them before the shopping event starts. The short time frame of the event will call for quick decisions and you want to be sure of your purchases.

    Review the return policy


    Most items purchased through Amazon have a 30-day return period after delivery. However, some items aren't returnable, such as products missing UPCs as well as gift cards, select jewelry items, and some health and personal care items.

    Resellers may also have a different return policy. Check the full return policy for all the details.

    More Deals To Save

    • Best TV Deals
    • Best Cell Phone Deals
    • Best Apple Deals

Label: When Is Amazon Prime Day? (220127_whenisamazonprimeday) (20 PV)
Body:
Forget the Fourth of July and Labor Day – the most anticipated shopping holiday of the summer is Amazon Prime Day. The online retailer's two-day shopping event that comes around every summer, Prime Day offers major discounts, deals, and limited-time flash sales for Amazon Prime members.

Sales aren’t limited to Amazon devices and products either. Shoppers can find Prime Day deals on a range of products, including TVs, laptops, gadgets, and so much more across the site.

Here’s what you should know about Amazon Prime Day – when it is, how it works, and what you should buy. But before you begin shopping, check out these Amazon coupons for possible extra savings on a variety of products.

When Is Amazon Prime Day?

Amazon Prime Day is set for July 11-12, 2023. You'll have 48 hours to shop some of the best deals available on the site until the holiday season. The event started in July 2015 and was only 24 hours long, but it's been two days long since 2019. Fortunately, if you happen to miss the designated sale days, there will still be deals on Amazon throughout the week.

Last year, Amazon introduced a second two-day sale event called Prime Early Access Sale, which took place Oct. 11-12. The event was similar to Prime Day and was meant to help shoppers get a head start on their holiday shopping. The Prime Early Access Sale may return this year, but we won't know for sure until Amazon announces it later in the year.

What Is Amazon Prime Day? 

Amazon Prime Day is an annual two-day sale that takes place on amazon.com. It started in 2015 as a single-day sale to celebrate the online retailer’s 20th birthday and boost revenue during the summer slump in sales. Since then, Prime Day has grown to a nearly week-long event with millions of discounts on everything from Fire TV sticks to coffee makers.

Last year was the biggest Prime Day yet with more than 300 million items purchased and more than $1.7 billion saved by shoppers – the most savings of any prior year, according to Amazon. The most popular items fell into these categories: Amazon devices, consumer electronics, and home products.

The discounts are only available to Amazon Prime members, so you’ll need to sign up for a Prime membership to access the exclusive deals.

If you don’t have a Prime membership, you can still score major discounts on Prime Day at other retailers. The sale has become quite popular, so other retailers like Walmart, Target, and Macy's now offer their own sales during Prime Day to compete with Amazon.

What Do I Need To Do To Shop on Amazon Prime Day? 

To take advantage of this year’s Amazon Prime Day deals, you must be an Amazon Prime member. It costs $14.99 per month or $139 per year for a regular membership, and $7.49 per month or $69 per year for students. Prime memberships also include dozens of perks, such as access to exclusive movies and TV shows on Prime Video, free two-, one-, and same-day delivery on qualifying items, and more.

Shoppers who aren't Prime members can sign up for a free 30-day trial membership. This will give you access to Prime Day deals without having to pay the monthly or annual membership fee, so long as you cancel the membership before the trial ends. A student Amazon Prime free trial lasts six months.
